name: Pegasus
abilities: Flight: Unlimited aerial movement and speed
Divine Grace: Born from divine blood, radiates sacred power
Stamina: Can fly for impossibly long distances without rest
Springwater Creation: Where Pegasus strikes the ground, magical springs emerge
Hero Companionship: Can form telepathic bonds with pure-hearted individuals
weaknesses: Moral Judgment: Refuses service to those with impure intentions
Sacred Bonds: If bonded, vulnerable through emotional connection
Mortality: While divine, can still be physically harmed by determined foes
habitat: Mount Helicon, springs sacred to the Muses, high mountain peaks
behavior: Noble, wise, protective of sacred spaces, bonds with worthy heroes

christian.overview: Pegasus, the divine winged horse born from Medusa's blood, became in Christian interpretation a powerful symbol of the soul's ascent to God, poetry inspired by the Holy Spirit, and the sublimation of chaos into divine service.

biblicalParallels.description: Elijah taken up by horses and chariot of fire parallels Pegasus as a vehicle of divine ascent.
Christ on the white horse, followed by heavenly armies on white horses, evokes the image of divine steeds bearing victorious riders.
God riding the cherub and making clouds his chariot parallels the theme of divine beings serving as mounts for celestial journeys.
Those who wait on the Lord "shall mount up with wings as eagles" parallels Pegasus's wing-borne ascent.

patristicInterpretation.summary: Church Fathers saw in Pegasus a symbol of how divine grace can bring good from evil (born from Medusa's death) and elevate the soul toward heavenly contemplation.

sources.author: Fulgentius
sources.interpretation: Interpreted Pegasus allegorically as fame or reputation born from virtue's victory over vice (Medusa). The wings represent how good reputation lifts one above earthly concerns.

sources.author: Boccaccio
sources.work: Genealogy of the Pagan Gods (Christian medieval perspective)
sources.interpretation: Saw Pegasus striking Hippocrene, the spring of poetic inspiration, as symbolizing how divine power (wings) opens channels of wisdom.

medievalSymbolism.bestiaryMeaning: Medieval thought associated Pegasus with poetic inspiration, which Christians interpreted as the Holy Spirit inspiring sacred writings.
medievalSymbolism.moralLesson: Bellerophon's fall from Pegasus when attempting to reach Olympus taught that human pride cannot storm heaven - ascent comes only by divine invitation, not human presumption.
medievalSymbolism.artisticRepresentation: Medieval manuscripts sometimes depicted divine inspiration or the soul's ascent using Pegasus imagery, though more common in Renaissance Christian Platonism.
medievalSymbolism.poeticConnection: Christian poets from Dante onward used the imagery of sacred flight and divine springs, continuing the Pegasus tradition of inspired ascent.

christian.typologicalReading: Pegasus born from Medusa's death prefigures how Christ brings life from death, good from evil. The monstrous mother's defeat yields a being of pure grace and beauty - a pattern of redemption.
christian.symbolismOfFlight: The wing as symbol of the soul's ascent to God became central to Christian mystical tradition. Pegasus's effortless flight represents the graced soul no longer bound by earthly weight.
christian.hippocreneConnection: The spring opened by Pegasus's hoof became a symbol for the fonts of sacred knowledge opened by divine power - paralleling baptismal symbolism of life-giving water from rock (Exodus 17:6).
